item.title: [Java] Spanish Verb Conjugator
item.dc:creator: @Epic_Steve Epic Steve
item.description:
@Epic_Steve wrote:

For example;

public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        /* This class doesn't have a constructor, or is using one that doesn't require any parameters */
        SomeClass someClass = new SomeClass();
        
       someClass.doSomething();      
    }
}

This is the main class, it looks exactly the same as your main class but without the same class or method names.

public class SomeClass {
    ...
    public void doSomething() {
           SomeNewClass someNewClass = new SomeNewClass(this);
    }
    ...
}

As you can see, I’m passing the keyword this as the parameter to SomeNewClass. The keyword this is an reference to itself. In this case, this, is referencing to SomeClass.

public class SomeNewClass {
    private SomeClass someClass;

    public SomeNewClass(SomeClass someClass) {
        this.someClass = someClass;
    }
    ...
}

Now, the SomeNewClass class has access to the someClass class without having to create a new instance. This is because in this class, you set the variable someClass to a reference of the someClass that was passed from the actual SomeClass. You no longer have to create a new instance of SomeClass, (eg; new SomeClass()); You can just use the someClass variable.

I’m sorry for not explaining this very well, I’m not very good at explaining things, maybe someone else can help me here?

Read full topic

item.title: [Java] Spanish Verb Conjugator
item.dc:creator: @sp11k3t3ht3rd sp11k3t3ht3rd
item.description:
@sp11k3t3ht3rd wrote:

Ehh… I get the use of constucters now, but not how to use it here. My book said to use it when things about the object need to be initialized before its used. But I don’t understand how the use you described above would work.

Read full topic

item.title: [Java] Spanish Verb Conjugator
item.dc:creator: @Epic_Steve Epic Steve
item.description:
@Epic_Steve wrote:

[quote=“sp11k3t3ht3rd, post:25, topic:388168”][quote author=Epic Steve link=topic=483983.msg3546864#msg3546864 date=1301243639]
EDIT: Also, instead of creating a new instance of SpanishVerbConjugator in every class, you could always pass the instance that’s created in the main method to the classes when needed, this is when the constructor comes in handy.
[/quote]

Ummmm… What? Haha I’m getting to constructors in just a few pages in my book. I’m sure I’ll understand that soon.[/quote]
Constructors are called when you create a new instance of a class, EG: new Main(); or whatever.

Now if I added this constructor to my Main class;

public Main(int someInteger)
{
    // do something with this integer
}

Notice that I don’t set a return type (void, int, boolean, ect), this is not a typo. When you’re writing constructors they can’t return anything (I know void is also returning nothing, but then how would you be able to tell the difference between a method and the constructor?), so you can’t write a return type, this is also how to identify constructors, they have no return type.

I now have to create a new instance of the Main class by doing;new Main(44);

EDIT: One more thing, you CAN have multiple constructors per class, you’re not just limited to 1.
You can also have constructors that don’t take parameters. I was just using that as an example. If you don’t understand something, let me know and I’ll try to explain it a little better with more code examples.

Read full topic

item.title: [Java] Spanish Verb Conjugator
item.dc:creator: @Epic_Steve Epic Steve
item.description:
@Epic_Steve wrote:

You could always change;

input.input.equals("Present") || input.input.equals("present")

To

input.input.equalsIgnoreCase("present")

And the same with all the other tenses.

EDIT: Also, instead of creating a new instance of SpanishVerbConjugator in every class, you could always pass the instance that’s created in the main method to the classes when needed, this is when the constructor comes in handy.

Read full topic

item.title: [Java] Spanish Verb Conjugator
item.dc:creator: @sp11k3t3ht3rd sp11k3t3ht3rd
item.description:
@sp11k3t3ht3rd wrote:

I’m working that out now. I’m not sure if I should make separate classes for the verbs or just put them into the separate tense classes that I’m working on. There are a lot of irregular verbs so I’m thinking that making separate classes for them is not a good idea. I’ll probably just put a check into the tense class that will change the irregular verbs to the correct conjugation. I’m trying to implement a little but of inheritance by reducing the amount of variables used, it’s not a very good use, it’s more for practice than anything. I’m making one class called verb tense which all the other classes will extend. There’s 1 abstract method that the other tense classes override and one that they will inherit. I’m finishing that up now.

EDIT: I’ve completed the inheritance. It’s my first attempt at using inheritance so I’m pretty pumped haha. The updated code is in the first post!

item.title: [Java] Spanish Verb Conjugator
item.dc:creator: @kingman002 kingman002
item.description:
@kingman002 wrote:

[quote=“Epic Steve, post:16, topic:388168”]Verbs in Japanese end in masu.
Unless, you’re saying something like, she doesn't eat then it ends in; masen. Which is basically a negative ending. There maybe other exceptions, but I don’t know yet. I’m only on CD 2 of 8.

EG:
She doesn’t eat: tabemasen
He doesn’t eat: tabemasen
I don’t eat: tabemasen

tabe is the verb to eat.

EDIT: PM me if you have anymore Japanese questions, I don’t want to spam up sp11k3t3ht3rd’s topic.

ONTOPIC:
I’ll look over this code tomorrow, as it’s quite late and I’ve been drinking tonight.[/quote]
The verb comer is spanish for to eat XD

Read full topic

Verbs in Japanese end in masu.
Unless, you’re saying something like, she doesn't eat then it ends in; masen. Which is basically a negative ending. There maybe other exceptions, but I don’t know yet. I’m only on CD 2 of 8.

EG:
She doesn’t eat: tabemasen
He doesn’t eat: tabemasen
I don’t eat: tabemasen

tabe is the verb to eat.

item.title: [Java] Spanish Verb Conjugator
item.dc:creator: @Epic_Steve Epic Steve
item.description:
@Epic_Steve wrote:

[quote=“sp11k3t3ht3rd, post:5, topic:388168”]Well just like with any language you have to conjugate verbs. EX: I talk, You talk, He/She/It talks, We talk, You All/They masculine & feminine talk. < Basically what this means but in Spanish:

[quote]Yo: hablo
T·: hablas
Usted, ╔l, Ella: habla
Nosotros: hablamos
Vosotros: hablßis
Ustedes, Ellos, Ellas: hablan[/quote][/quote]
Except in Japanese.

In Japanese;
The ending doesn’t change no matter who is doing it word, it always ends in masu.

EG:
I eat in Japanese is tabemasu;
She eats in Japanese is tabemasu
You eat is Japanese is tabemasu.

Haha. Sorry for the quick Japanese lesson,

Read full topic
